text: people in South Sudan know when trouble
is coming they've been running from war
for decades this dusty strung-out town
is been tu capital of a state rich in
oil and rebel-held but even the soldiers
who switch sides know the wind is
changing thousands fled here to the
safety of a UN compound when the town
fell t weeks ago when which tribe you
were from suddenly became a question of
life or death they come in our home in
the midnight and they greet us in the
Dinka language when we reply it they
start shooting they have food and clean
water but supplies are short it's no
place for a baby to be born I'm worried
about fighting I'm worried about is
staying here for how long are we going
to stay here and the fighting is coming
to bend to you again the frontline
suddenly shifted the government troops
advancing we thought the battle had
begun but this was the rebels destroying
ammunition they couldn't retreat with
more people in need of help but with
food running low here the UN decided to
take a risk
an aid mission into town to fetch food
supplies from a UN warehouse as
civilians continued to flee this is a UN
compound in the center of bent EU they
came here to pick up food to take it
back to the camp before the fighting
started have you come through this area
overnight more than a thousand people
came into this compound to try and get
shelter from the fighting and now
they've become the priority now the UN
is going to take these people and get
them out hopefully before the fighting
starts
with gunfire already heard nearby they
had to be fast
there is never enough time when an
opportunity like this comes along
nor is there enough lead they took who
they could and would return for the rest
raisin they reached the camp safely but
the mission for food brought only more
people and the historical rift between
tribes has been reopened by this crisis
while talks about peace go nowhere
the fear is more fighting will come
alistair leave dead BBC news in been to
South Sudan
